questions.text: A patient presented with vision loss. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the optic chiasma was noted. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the artery that is causing the damage?
questions.solution:
Answer A - Anterior communicating artery

  • The optic chiasma is located just above the anterior communicating artery (AComA) in the suprasellar cistern. Aneurysms of the AComA are the most common intracranial aneurysms and can compress the optic chiasma, leading to bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes). These aneurysms often present with vision loss, headaches, and possibly subarachnoid hemorrhage if they rupture.

 

 

Anterior choroidal artery (option B): This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and posterior limb of the internal capsule. Aneurysms here are rare and typically cause contralateral motor deficits rather than optic chiasma compression.

Middle cerebral artery (option C): The MCA does not course near the optic chiasma. MCA aneurysms more commonly affect the lateral convexity of the brain, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant hemisphere), or neglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

Anterior cerebral artery (option D): The ACA courses superior to the optic chiasma, but aneurysms at this location usually do not cause direct compression. ACA infarcts more commonly lead to leg weakness (contralateral) due to involvement of the paracentral lobule.

questions.text:
Which of the following options are included in the limbic system? 

1. Amygdala 

2. Hippocampus 

3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
Answer: A) 1,2

 

Explanation:

The limbic system is a collection of brain structures involved in emotion, memory, and motivation. The key components of the limbic system include:

  1. Amygdala → Plays a crucial role in emotion processing, particularly fear and aggression.
  2. Hippocampus → Essential for learning and memory, particularly long-term memory formation.

Other Major Components of the Limbic System:

  • Hypothalamus → Regulates autonomic functions and emotional responses.
  • Cingulate gyrus → Involved in emotion formation and processing.
  • Mammillary bodies → Associated with memory processing.

 

Thalamus: While the thalamus is important for sensory relay, it is not strictly part of the limbic system. However, some parts of the thalamus (e.g., anterior nucleus and dorsomedial nucleus) are functionally linked to the limbic system.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Abducens nerve

 

Explanation:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) arises from the pontomedullary junction, specifically from the ventral surface of the brainstem, near the midline.

It travels forward to innervate the lateral rectus muscle, which controls abduction of the eye (lateral movement).

 

Attachment of the nerves to the brain:

  • 1, 2 - Forebrain
  • 3- Arises from ventral midbrain
  • 4- Dorsal midbrain (cannot see its origin in the Anterior view of the brainstem)
  • 5- Lateral pons
  • 6, 7, 8- Ponto medullary junction (from medial to lateral respectively)
  • 9, 10, 11- Lateral to olives (from superior to inferior respectively)
  • 12- Between pyramid and olives

 

Oculomotor nerve (option A): The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the midbrain (interpeduncular fossa), not the pontomedullary junction.

 

Glossopharyngeal nerve (option B): The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) emerges from the medulla, specifically the postolivary sulcus, above the vagus nerve, not from the pontomedullary junction.

 

Facial nerve (option D): The facial nerve (CN VII) also arises from the pontomedullary junction, but it is located laterally, near the cerebellopontine angle. The abducens nerve is more medial, while the facial nerve is lateral to it.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia:- 

1. Striatum 

2. Globus pallidus 

3. Substantia nigra 

4. Thalamus 

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Answer: C) 5,1,2,3,4

Explanation:

Cortex (5) → Initiates movement and sends excitatory signals to the striatum.

Striatum (1) (Caudate + Putamen) → Receives input from the cortex and modulates basal ganglia output.

Globus pallidus (2) (Internal and External segments) → Affects the output to the thalamus.

Substantia nigra (3) (Pars compacta and Pars reticulata) → Modulates the activity of the striatum and globus pallidus.

Thalamus (4) → Relays processed signals back to the cortex for movement execution.

 

Direct Pathway:

 

  • Promotes movement by reducing inhibitory output from the GPi to the thalamus.
  • Mechanism: The striatum inhibits the GPi, leading to less inhibition of the thalamus and increased motor activity.

 

Indirect Pathway:

 

  • Inhibits movement by increasing inhibitory output from the GPe to the thalamus.
  • Mechanism: The striatum inhibits the GPe, resulting in less inhibition of the STN, which then excites the GPi. This increased activity of the GPi leads to more inhibition of the thalamus and decreased motor activity.


 

 

Direct Pathway

Indirect Pathway

Function

Facilitates motor activity

Suppresses motor activity

Input

Excitatory input from the cerebral cortex

Excitatory input from the cerebral cortex

Target

Striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen)

Striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen)

Striatum Output

Inhibits internal segment of globus pallidus (GPi)

Inhibits external segment of globus pallidus (GPe)

GPi/SNr Effect

Reduced inhibition of thalamus

Increased inhibition of thalamus

Thalamus Effect

Increased thalamic activation

Decreased thalamic activation

Motor Cortex Effect

Enhanced motor activity

Reduced motor activity

Subthalamic Nucleus (STN)

Not directly involved

Activated by reduced inhibition from GPe

questions.text: Neostriatum consists of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

Explanation:

  • The neostriatum (or striatum) consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen. These structures are functionally and anatomically linked as part of the basal ganglia, playing a crucial role in motor control and cognitive functions.

Components of the Basal Ganglia

Component

Includes

Function

Striatum (Neostriatum)

Caudate nucleus + Putamen

Main input center of the basal ganglia, receives input from the cortex

Lentiform nucleus

Putamen + Globus pallidus

Part of the extrapyramidal motor system, regulates movement

Globus pallidus

Internal (medial) and External (lateral) segments

Main output structure, modulates thalamocortical circuits

Subthalamic nucleus

Located in the diencephalon

Plays a role in modulating basal ganglia output

Substantia nigra

Located in the midbrain

Produces dopamine; degeneration leads to Parkinson’s disease

 

Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus (Option A): Incorrect because globus pallidus is not part of the neostriatum.

Globus pallidus and putamen (Option B): Incorrect because globus pallidus belongs to the paleostriatum, not neostriatum.

Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus (Option C): Incorrect because lentiform nucleus includes putamen and globus pallidus, but the neostriatum consists only of caudate and putamen.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is accompanied by his wife to the Neurology OPD. His wife expressed concern about her husband's condition and they were directed to this facility by a local doctor. According to the doctor's note, the patient is unable to repeat spoken words but can comprehend them and respond appropriately by nodding. The patient also experiences difficulty in naming people and writing. The doctor referred the patient to a specialized facility for a CT brain scan. As the intern on duty, you would inform the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) that this condition could be indicative of a brain lesion in which specific area?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Arcuate fasciculus

Explanation:

  • Difficulty in repeating spoken words, trouble with naming and writing, yet intact comprehension of spoken language, suggests Conduction Aphasia.
  • It's caused by a disconnection between language centers in the brain, possibly affecting the Arcuate Fasciculus.
  • This white matter tract links Broca's area (speech production) with Wernicke's area (language comprehension).
  • Damage here can lead to symptoms like those described in conduction aphasia, where patients struggle to repeat words or phrases accurately despite understanding them.

Aphasia Type

Area Affected

Features

Broca's Aphasia

Left frontal lobe (Broca's area)

Non-fluent speech, difficulty forming sentences, good comprehension, and poor writing/speech output.

Wernicke's Aphasia

Left temporal lobe (Wernicke's area)

Fluent speech with normal grammar, but speech is nonsensical or meaningless, poor comprehension.

Conduction Aphasia

Arcuate fasciculus (connecting Broca's and Wernicke's areas)

Difficulty repeating words or phrases, fluent speech with errors, good comprehension.

Global Aphasia

Widespread damage to left hemisphere (Broca's, Wernicke's, and arcuate fasciculus)

Severe communication deficits: non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and inability to repeat.

 

Incorrect Options:

Anterior commissure (Option B): The anterior commissure is involved in the connection between the two cerebral hemispheres but is not typically associated with the specific language symptoms described.

Corpus callosum (Option C): Damage to the corpus callosum can result in a variety of symptoms but is not specifically associated with the language deficits described.

Fornix (Option D): The fornix is a white matter structure involved in memory processes but is not typically associated with the language symptoms described.

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) L3

Explanation:

At birth, the spinal cord extends down to L3, but as the child grows, the vertebral column elongates more than the spinal cord, and by adulthood, it typically ends at L1-L2.

Spinal Cord Termination in Different Ages

Age Group

Spinal Cord Termination Level

Clinical Relevance

Fetus (24 weeks)

Extends to S1

Early spinal development stage

Newborn (Infants)

Ends at L3

Important for lumbar puncture site selection

Adults

Ends at L1-L2

Safe lumbar puncture site is L3-L4 or L4-L5

L1 (Option A): Incorrect because in infants, the spinal cord does not end as high as L1; this is the adult level.

L2 (Option B): Incorrect because the spinal cord in newborns extends lower, typically to L3.

L4 (Option D): Incorrect because while the spinal cord is lower in fetuses, in infants, it usually stops at L3, not L4.

questions.text: In this image of basal ganglia, all of the following are correctly labeled except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4- Internal capsule

 

Explanation:

The internal capsule is a white matter tract separating the caudate nucleus from the putamen and globus pallidus, whereas the structure labeled as 4 in the image corresponds to the thalamus, which is a relay center for sensory and motor signals.

Basal Ganglia Anatomy

Structure

Function

Location

Caudate nucleus

Motor processes, learning, associative functions

Lateral to lateral ventricle, near thalamus

Putamen

Regulates movements, influences learning

Part of the striatum, lateral to globus pallidus

Globus pallidus

Inhibitory control of movements

Medial to putamen, part of lentiform nucleus

Internal capsule

Contains motor and sensory pathways

Between caudate nucleus and lentiform nucleus

Thalamus

Sensory relay station

Medial to basal ganglia, near third ventricle

1 - Caudate nucleus (Option A): Forms part of the striatum, involved in motor control.

2 - Globus pallidus (Option B): Part of the lentiform nucleus, modulates motor activity.

3 - Putamen (Option C): Works with the caudate to regulate movements.

questions.text:
Identify the nerve passing through the marked structure?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oculomotor nerve

 

Explanation:

  • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the midbrain and enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure.
  • It supplies the majority of the extraocular muscles:
    • Superior rectus, Inferior rectus, Medial rectus, Inferior oblique
    • Also levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) for eyelid elevation
  • It carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion, which control pupillary constriction.
  • The marked structure is located in the superior orbital fissure, where CN III travels.

Oculomotor Nerve and Its Functions

Feature

Description

Cranial Nerve

CN III

Origin

Midbrain (interpeduncular fossa)

Course

Passes through the cavernous sinus, then through the superior orbital fissure

Muscles Supplied

Superior rectus, Inferior rectus, Medial rectus, Inferior oblique, Levator palpebrae superioris

Parasympathetic Function

Pupil constriction (via ciliary ganglion)

Clinical Importance

CN III palsy causes ptosis, down-and-out gaze, and pupil dilation

Abducens nerve (Option B): Incorrect because CN VI innervates only the lateral rectus muscle and is located more medially in the superior orbital fissure.

Trochlear nerve (Option C): Incorrect because CN IV innervates only the superior oblique muscle, and it is the smallest cranial nerve, running more laterally.

Ophthalmic division (Option D): Incorrect because the ophthalmic division of CN V (V1) is a sensory nerve, not involved in eye muscle movement.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise?
questions.solution:
• The image is a coronal CT scan of the orbit, highlighting the extraocular muscles, specifically the medial rectus muscles (marked structures).
  • The medial rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which originates from the oculomotor nucleus in the midbrain.
  • The oculomotor nucleus receives input from the Red Nucleus, which is involved in coordinating eye movements and muscle tone through the rubro-oculomotor connections.
  • The Red Nucleus is an important structure in the midbrain tegmentum, involved in motor coordination, particularly in controlling extraocular muscles via the rubro-oculomotor pathway. It plays a role in conjugate gaze and eye movement control, making it relevant to the medial rectus function.

Oculomotor Nerve and Its Control

Structure

Function

Oculomotor Nucleus (Midbrain)

Origin of CN III, controls most extraocular muscles

Red Nucleus (Midbrain)

Regulates motor coordination and eye movements via rubro-oculomotor pathways

Edinger-Westphal Nucleus

Provides parasympathetic fibers for pupil constriction and accommodation

Medial Rectus Muscle

Controlled by CN III, responsible for adduction of the eye

Blood Supply

Supplied by paramedian branches of the basilar artery and PCA

Clinical Correlation

Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis, mydriasis, and eye deviation ("down and out")

Subthalamic Nucleus (Option B): Incorrect because it is primarily involved in indirect basal ganglia pathways and has no direct role in extraocular muscle control.

Decussation of Pyramidal Tract (Option C): Incorrect because it primarily relates to corticospinal tract fibers, which control voluntary movements of the limbs, not the eyes.

Olivary Nucleus (Option D): Incorrect because it is part of the olivocerebellar system, which is responsible for motor learning and coordination, rather than direct eye movement control.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure?

choices.text: Scalp synchondral membrane, dura mater, arachnoid mater

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scalp, dura mater, arachnoid mater

Explanation:

  • The anterior fontanelle is the largest fontanelle in an infant and remains open until around 18 months. It provides an accessible site for cranial ultrasound and CSF sampling in neonates.
  • During CSF sampling via the anterior fontanelle, the needle pierces:
    • Scalp (including skin and subcutaneous tissue)
    • Dura mater (outermost meningeal layer)
    • Arachnoid mater (middle meningeal layer)
  • The pia mater is not pierced as it remains intact while CSF is drawn from the subarachnoid space.

Anterior Fontanelle and CSF Sampling

Feature

Details

Location

Intersection of frontal and parietal bones

Closure

12-18 months

Clinical Uses

CSF sampling in neonates

Cranial ultrasound to assess hydrocephalus or hemorrhage

Structures Pierced

Scalp → Dura mater → Arachnoid mater → CSF space

Why Not Endocranium?

The endocranium is part of the bone, which is not yet ossified at the fontanelle.

 

Scalp, epicranium, dura mater (Option B): incorrect because the epicranium is a broad term for the scalp layers, but arachnoid mater is missing, which is an essential layer pierced in CSF sampling.

Scalp, synchondral membrane, dura mater, arachnoid mater (Option C): incorrect because there is no synchondral membrane at the fontanelle; it is composed of fibrous tissue, not cartilage.

Pericranium, dura mater, endocranium (Option D): incorrect because endocranium is the inner table of the skull, which is not yet ossified at the fontanelle. The arachnoid mater is also missing in this option.

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

Explanation:

The lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature sensations. The patient has loss of sensation in both upper and lower limbs, shooting pain, and a burning sensation when touching cold water, indicating damage to this pathway. Motor function is intact, ruling out motor tract involvement.

Lateral Spinothalamic Tract

Feature

Description

Function

Transmits pain and temperature sensations

Decussation (Crossing)

Crosses to the opposite side at the level of entry in the spinal cord

Pathway

Ascends in the spinal cord → synapses in the thalamus → projects to the sensory cortex

Lesion Effects

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion

 

Dorsal Horn (Option A) - Incorrect: It processes sensory information but does not transmit pain and temperature to higher centers. Lesion here would cause segmental sensory loss, not widespread involvement.

Ventral Horn (Option C) - Incorrect: Contains lower motor neurons, so a lesion here would cause motor weakness or paralysis, which is absent in this case.

Dorsal Root Ganglion (Option D) - Incorrect: Damage would result in dermatomal sensory loss, not the widespread sensory deficit seen in this patient.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the mammillary body, which is part of the Papez circuit, responsible for memory processing. The mammillothalamic tract carries fibers from the mammillary bodies to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus further relays this information to the cingulate gyrus, playing a crucial role in learning and memory.

Mammillary Bodies and Their Connections

Feature

Details

Structure

Mammillary bodies (part of the hypothalamus)

Pathway

Mammillothalamic tract

Target in Thalamus

Anterior nucleus of the thalamus

Function

Memory processing, part of the Papez circuit

Clinical Significance

Damage leads to memory deficits (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)

Posterior nucleus (Option A): Incorrect, as it is involved in pain perception and thermoregulation, not in the Papez circuit.

Reticular nucleus (Option B): Incorrect, as it regulates thalamocortical activity but does not receive direct input from the mammillary bodies.

Ventral lateral nucleus (Option D): Incorrect, as it is involved in motor relay from the cerebellum and basal ganglia, not memory processing.

questions.text: The type of fibers present in the fornix are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Association and commissural fibers

Explanation:

  • The fornix, vital for memory and limbic system functions, comprises association fibers and commissural fibers. Association fibers links nearby brain regions within the same hemisphere, like the hippocampus, mamillary bodies, and septal nuclei. Commissural fibers connect the hippocampus of one hemisphere to its counterpart in the other hemisphere through the anterior commissure.

 

Commissural fibres

Projection

Association

They connect one hemisphere to the opposite side, linking corresponding (homotopic) or different (heterotopic) areas. Eg:

  • Corpus Callosum: The largest commissural structure connecting the two cerebral hemispheres, located at the bottom of the longitudinal fissure.
  • Anterior Commissure: A smaller bundle of nerve fibres crossing the midline at the lamina terminalis.
  • Fornix: Composed of myelinated fibres, it connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies in the hypothalamus. It connects the hippocampal formations of the 2 sides

Projection fibres connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures, including the brainstem and spinal cord, and include both descending (corticofugal) and ascending (corticopetal) fibres.

These fibres converge in the corona radiata, pass through the internal capsule, and are flanked by the caudate nucleus and thalamus medially, and the lentiform nucleus laterally.

Association tracts connect different areas within the same hemisphere.

Eg: Arcuate fasciculus

 

Association and projection fibers (Option B): Projection fibers link the cerebral cortex with other brain areas or the spinal cord. However, projection fibers are not a major component of the fornix.

Commissural and projection fibers (Option C): Commissural fibers connect corresponding regions between the two cerebral hemispheres, but projection fibers are not a significant part of the fornix.

Association fibers (Option D): Association fibers are involved in connecting different regions within the same hemisphere. However, the fornix also contains commissural fibers.

questions.text: The neurotransmitter secreted by the area marked in the given image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dopamine

Explanation:

  • The marked area corresponds to the substantia nigra, located in the midbrain. It's pivotal for producing and releasing dopamine, a neurotransmitter crucial for motor control, reward and motivation, and emotional regulation. Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra release dopamine into areas like the basal ganglia, vital for voluntary movements and motor coordination.

 

Internal Structure of the Midbrain

  • The midbrain consists of the posterior part (tectum) and the large anterior part (cerebral peduncle).
  • The cerebral peduncle is divided into three regions: tegmentum, substantia nigra, and crus cerebri.
  • Substantia nigra and crus cerebri remain consistent throughout sections.

Crus Cerebri:

  • The medial two-thirds of the crus cerebri contains corticonuclear and corticospinal fibers.
  • The medial one-third of the crus contains frontopontine fibers.
  • The lateral one-third of the crus contains temporopontine, parietopontine, and occipitopontine fibers.

Substantia Nigra:

  • A pigmented band of gray matter situated between the tegmentum and the crus cerebri.
  • It is a large motor nucleus that spans the length of the midbrain.
  • The substantia nigra is divided into pars compacta and pars reticularis.
  • It contains melanin (a precursor to dopamine) and iron.
  • The substantia nigra synthesizes dopamine, which is transmitted via axons to the corpus striatum.

 

 

Acetylcholine (Option A):

  • Acetylcholine influences muscle contraction, memory, and learning, but it's not primarily secreted by the substantia nigra.

 

Glutamine (Option C):

  • Glutamine is an amino acid that serves as a building block for proteins in the body. It is not a neurotransmitter involved in the substantia nigra's function.

 

Noradrenaline (Option D):

  • Noradrenaline, crucial for the "fight-or-flight" response and attention, is primarily produced in the locus coeruleus, not the substantia nigra.

questions.text: The medial lemniscus is a continuation of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fasciculus gracilis

Explanation:

  • The medial lemniscus is a continuation of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus, which are part of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway. This pathway carries sensory information related to fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the lower body (fasciculus gracilis) and upper body (fasciculus cuneatus) to the brain.
  • The fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus are composed of ascending sensory fibers that originate from the dorsal root ganglia in the spinal cord.

 

Dorsal Column (Posterior Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway):

 

Category

Details

Components

Fasciculus Gracilis: Carries sensory information from the lower limbs (Option C)

Fasciculus Cuneatus: Carries sensory information from the upper limbs

Sensations

Pressure

Tactile discrimination

Vibration

Conscious Proprioception

Stereognosis

Neuronal Pathway

1st Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal root ganglion

2nd Order Neuron: Located in the medulla oblongata

3rd Order Neuron: Located in the thalamus

Spinothalamic tract (Option A): The spinothalamic tract is a separate pathway that carries pain, temperature, and crude touch sensations from the body to the thalamus.

Spinocerebellar tract (Option B): The spinocerebellar tracts are involved in carrying proprioceptive information from the spinal cord to the cerebellum, which helps in coordinating and fine-tuning motor movements.

Spinotectal tract (Option C): The spinotectal tract is involved in conveying sensory information related to pain and temperature from the body to the superior colliculus in the midbrain, which plays a role in orienting visual and auditory responses to stimuli.

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Midbrain

Explanation:

  • The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is one of the three major fiber tracts that connect the cerebellum with the rest of the brain. It is located on the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.
  • The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle refers to the crossing over of its fibers from one side of the brainstem to the other. This decussation occurs at the level of the midbrain, specifically in the region called the upper midbrain tegmentum.

Cerebellar Peduncle:
It connects the cerebellum to the brainstem.

  • Superior cerebellar peduncle connects the cerebellum to the midbrain.
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle connects the cerebellum to the pons.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle connects the cerebellum to the medulla.

Pons (Option A): While the pons is involved in the transmission of various neural signals, the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle does not occur at this level.

Diencephalon (Option C): The diencephalon, housing the thalamus and hypothalamus, lies above the midbrain. The superior cerebellar peduncle's decussation doesn't happen within the diencephalon.

Medulla (Option D): While the medulla is involved in various vital functions, including cardiovascular and respiratory control, the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle does not occur at the level of the medulla.

questions.text: Where is the probable location of the lesion in a patient who has presented with weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face along with loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left leg?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Lateral medulla

Explanation:

  • The clinical features described—weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face, along with loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left leg—are indicative of a lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome.
  • In this condition, there is damage to the lateral part of the medulla.
  • This syndrome typically involves the spinothalamic tract (for pain and temperature sensation), the descending trigeminal tract (for facial sensation), and other structures like the nucleus ambiguus (which affects the motor function of the larynx and pharynx).

 

Wallenberg Syndrome (Lateral Medullary Syndrome)

  • Due to stroke or infarction in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata.
  • Mainly due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery. Sometimes the vertebral artery directly supplies the lateral brainstem.
  • Affects the dorsolateral aspect of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum.

 

Anatomical structure affected and features:

  1. Spinothalamic tract: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the trunk.
  2. Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face.
  3. Nucleus ambiguus: Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx.
  4. Inferior cerebellar peduncle and cerebellum: Ipsilateral ataxia.
  5. Vestibular nuclei: Giddiness.

 

 

Medial medulla (option A): Lesions here typically affect the medial lemniscus (responsible for touch and proprioception) and corticospinal tract (which affects motor function). This would cause contralateral weakness and loss of touch/proprioception, but not facial pain/temperature loss.

Lateral pons (option B): Lesions in the lateral pons often affect the spinothalamic tract and trigeminal nerve (similar to the lateral medulla), but this would typically involve contralateral body symptoms, not the contralateral leg. The face could have sensory loss on the same side, but the involvement of the left leg would point more toward the medulla.

Medial pons (option C): A lesion here would primarily affect structures like the corticospinal tract, abducens nucleus, and the medial lemniscus, leading to contralateral motor deficits and sensory loss of the body. Facial pain/temperature loss would not occur with a medial pontine lesion.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Superior cerebellar artery (SCA)

Explanation:

  • The SCA supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain. Thrombosis of this artery leads to cerebellar ataxia, incoordination, dysmetria, and sometimes vertigo due to cerebellar dysfunction. The symptoms primarily affect balance, limb coordination, and gait stability.

Midbrain Blood Supply:

  • Anterior-Medial Supply: branches of the Basilar artery
  • Anterior-Lateral Supply: branches of the Posterior Choroidal arteries and Quadrigeminal artery from the Posterior Cerebral Artery
  • Posterior Supply: Quadrigeminal Artery and Superior Cerebellar Artery

Incorrect Options:

Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) (option A): Incorrect because PCA infarcts primarily affect the occipital lobe, leading to visual deficits (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) rather than ataxia.

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) (option B): Incorrect because MCA occlusion leads to contralateral motor and sensory deficits (especially in the face and upper limb) and aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved), but not significant ataxia.

Internal carotid artery (ICA) (option C): Incorrect because ICA occlusion affects multiple territories, mainly causing hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and aphasia rather than isolated cerebellar ataxia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for the identification of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

Explanation:

  • The inferior belly of omohyoid muscle is not used for identifying the facial nerve trunk because it is located in the lower neck and does not have any anatomical relation to the facial nerve. The facial nerve exits the stylomastoid foramen and is identified in the parotid region, where it divides into its branches.

Origin:

  • The facial nerve arises from the pons, a part of the brainstem, at the pontomedullary junction.

Pathway:

  • After its origin, the facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).
  • It then travels through the facial canal within the temporal bone.

 

Key Structures Along Its Course

Geniculate Ganglion:

  • Located within the facial canal, this is a sensory ganglion where the nerve fibers for taste (from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue) and some general sensory fibers synapse.

Branches within the Facial Canal:

  • Greater Petrosal Nerve: Arises from the geniculate ganglion, carrying parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland and nasal mucosa.
  • Chorda Tympani: This branch arises after the geniculate ganglion and carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.

 

Exit from the Skull

Stylomastoid Foramen:

  • The facial nerve exits the skull here, located between the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone.

 

Extracranial part of facial nerve:

 

Entry into Parotid Gland
  • The main trunk enters on the posteromedial surface of the parotid gland.

Division of Nerve
  • Divides within the gland, behind and superficial to the retromandibular vein and external carotid artery (ECA).

Temporofacial vs. Cervicofacial Trunks
  • Temporofacial trunk: Contains more axons but fewer fascicles.
  • Cervicofacial trunk: Contains more fascicles but fewer axons.

Formation of Parotid Plexus
  • The trunks branch further to form the parotid plexus (pes anserinus) from which the terminal branches arise.

Terminal Branches
  • Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical.

 

Incorrect Options:

Retrograde dissection from distal branch (option A): In cases where the main trunk is difficult to locate, tracing a distal branch backward helps in identifying the facial nerve trunk.

Tragal pointer (option B): The tragal pointer (cartilaginous structure of the external auditory canal) is an important surgical landmark, located about 1 cm anterior and inferior to the stylomastoid foramen, where the facial nerve trunk emerges.

Posterior belly of digastric (option D): The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another key landmark. The facial nerve trunk is located just superior to this muscle at its attachment to the mastoid process.

questions.text: An exhausted man was brought to the casualty with minimal response. He had a progressive history of weakness in his body for 2 days with facial droop, and slurring speech. Which vessel is likely to be thrombosed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Middle cerebral artery

Explanation:

  • MCA stroke best explains the symptoms (facial droop, weakness, slurred speech), making option C the correct choice.

Middle cerebral artery

  • Temporal lobe: Deafness, Wernicke aphasia, auditory hallucinations

Posterior cerebral artery (Option A)

Occipital lobe, inferior aspect of temporal lobe, splenium of corpus callosum

  • Temporal lobe: Incapacity to create and store new memory

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) thrombosis (Option D):

  • Causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) with dizziness, ataxia, dysphagia, and Horner's syndrome

Correct Answer: C) Lentiform nucleus

Explanation:

  • The structure marked in the image is the Lentiform nucleus. This structure is a part of the basal ganglia and consists of two components: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It plays a key role in motor control and coordination.

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with lesion below shown. This would result in which kind of field abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bitemporal hemianopia:

  • Craniopharyngiomas are often located near the pituitary gland and the optic chiasm. A tumor in this area can compress the optic chiasm, which affects the crossing fibers of the optic nerves from the nasal (medial) fields of vision. This results in loss of vision in the temporal (lateral) fields of both eyes, known as bitemporal hemianopia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Homonymous hemianopia: This type of vision loss occurs when there is damage to the optic tract or the visual cortex, leading to loss of vision in the same field of both eyes (either left or right). This is not typically associated with craniopharyngiomas.

Option C - Complete blindness: Complete blindness would occur with damage to both the optic nerves or the visual pathways at a more extensive level, not just from a craniopharyngioma affecting the optic chiasm.

Option D - Single vision field loss: This would imply a unilateral field loss, which is not characteristic of craniopharyngiomas. They usually affect the visual fields in a bitemporal manner due to their location affecting the optic chiasm.

questions.text: Identify the defect in the given image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Open neural tube defect

Explanation:

The given image depicts a newborn with an open neural tube defect, specifically rachischisis or myeloschisis, which is a severe form of spina bifida where the neural tissue is exposed without skin or meningeal covering.


 

Neural tube defects:

Category

Details

Definition

Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly.

Inheritance

Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance.

Maternal risk factors

Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency.

Types of NTDs

Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly.

Spina bifida occulta

Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence.

Craniorachischisis

Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus.

Meningocele

Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering.

Myelomeningocele

Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation.

Anencephaly

Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore.

Iniencephaly

Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect.

Prenatal diagnosis

Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).

Prevention

0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child).

Risk of recurrence

3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children.

Treatment

Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present.

 

Meningoencephalocele (Option B): Incorrect because a meningoencephalocele is a sac-like protrusion of meninges and brain tissue through a skull defect, typically in the occipital region.

Occult Spina Bifida (Option C): Incorrect because occult spina bifida is a closed defect where the vertebral arch fails to fuse, but the skin remains intact, often presenting with subtle external markers like a tuft of hair or dimple.

Encephalocele (Option D): is a rare birth defect that occurs when the neural tube doesn't close completely during fetal development. This results in a sac-like protrusion of brain tissue or membranes through a hole in the skull.

questions.text: The nerve passing through the red arrow marked region has been lesioned. Which of the following will be the clinical presentation?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation in scalp and nose

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Loss of sensation in scalp and nose:

  • The superior orbital fissure is a crucial anatomical opening in the skull through which several important nerves pass. These include the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), abducens nerve (CN VI), and the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).
  • The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the scalp, forehead, upper eyelid, nose, and the mucosa of the frontal sinuses. If the nerve passing through the superior orbital fissure is lesioned, the patient would experience loss of sensation in the scalp and nose due to the impairment of the ophthalmic nerve (V1).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx:

  • Incorrect: This sensation is typically provided by branches of the maxillary nerve (V2) and glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not by the ophthalmic nerve (V1), which passes through the superior orbital fissure.

Option B - Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face:

  • Incorrect: The maxillary division (V2) of the trigeminal nerve provides sensation to the maxillary region, but it exits the skull through the foramen rotundum, not the superior orbital fissure.

Option C - Loss of sensation in jaw area:

  • Incorrect: The mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve provides sensation to the jaw, but it exits through the foramen ovale, not the superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: Identify the arrow marked nerve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medial pectoral nerve:

  • The medial pectoral nerve arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the pectoralis minor and part of the pectoralis major muscles. The nerve typically pierces the pectoralis minor before reaching the pectoralis major. In an anatomical image or dissection, the medial pectoral nerve can be identified as the nerve that passes through or near the pectoralis minor and then continues to supply the pectoralis major.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lateral Pectoral Nerve:

  • The lateral pectoral nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and primarily innervates the pectoralis major muscle. Unlike the medial pectoral nerve, it does not pierce the pectoralis minor but rather passes above it. The lateral pectoral nerve is generally found more laterally and superiorly than the medial pectoral nerve.

Option C - Long Thoracic Nerve:

  • The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle. It runs down the side of the thorax and can be seen on the surface of the serratus anterior. It is not associated with the pectoral muscles and is positioned more posteriorly and laterally compared to the pectoral nerves.

Option D - Thoracodorsal Nerve:

  • The thoracodorsal nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle. It is found on the posterior side of the thorax and is not involved with the pectoral muscles, making it distinct from the medial pectoral nerve.

questions.text: Ptosis in horner’s syndrome is due to paralysis of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Superior Tarsal Muscle (Müller's Muscle):

  • This muscle is a smooth muscle that assists the levator palpebrae superioris in raising the upper eyelid. In Horner's syndrome, there is a disruption of the sympathetic innervation, leading to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle. This results in a mild ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Orbitalis:

  • Incorrect: The orbitalis muscle (also known as Müller's muscle) is not directly involved in eyelid movement but is instead associated with the structure of the orbit. It is not the cause of ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

Option C - Orbicularis Oculi:

  • Incorrect: The orbicularis oculi muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It is not affected in Horner's syndrome and is not responsible for ptosis.

Option D - Sphincter Pupillae:

  • Incorrect: The sphincter pupillae muscle is responsible for constricting the pupil and is innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system. It is not involved in eyelid movement and is not the cause of ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: What are the effects of a lesion in Brodmann area 22?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Receptive aphasia:

  • Brodmann area 22, also known as Wernicke's area, is primarily responsible for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to difficulties in understanding spoken and written language, resulting in receptive aphasia. Patients with this condition can speak fluently but often produce nonsensical sentences and have trouble understanding others.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Expressive aphasia: This is typically associated with damage to Brodmann area 44 and 45 (Broca's area) rather than Brodmann area 22. Expressive aphasia affects speech production, making it difficult for the patient to form grammatically correct sentences.

Option C - Poor repetition of language: Poor repetition of language is often linked to damage in the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke's area and Broca's area, rather than directly to Brodmann area 22.

Option D - Poor naming: Poor naming is often associated with damage to areas involved in language processing and retrieval, such as the left temporal lobe, but not specifically with Brodmann area 22 alone.

questions.text: A patient with loss of sensation on lateral 31/2 hand and thenar atrophy. Which nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Median:

  • Lateral 3½ fingers (thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of ring finger) on the palmar side are supplied sensory-wise by the median nerve.

  • Thenar atrophy suggests motor loss to thenar muscles, which are innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

  • These two features together are classic for median nerve injury, typically at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome) or more proximally.

Nerves of the hand:

Nerve

Motor Dysfunction

Sensory Dysfunction

Common Deformity/Condition

Median Nerve

Weakness of thenar muscles (thumb opposition), flexor muscles of forearm

Loss of sensation in lateral 3.5 fingers (thumb, index, middle, half of the ring finger)

Ape hand (thenar atrophy), Carpal tunnel syndrome

Ulnar Nerve (Option B ruled out)

Weakness of intrinsic hand muscles (especially interossei), hypothenar muscles

Loss of sensation in medial 1.5 fingers (little and half of the ring finger)

Claw hand, Hypothenar atrophy, Cubital tunnel syndrome

Radial Nerve (Option C ruled out)

Inability to extend wrist and fingers (wrist drop)

Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand

Wrist drop, Saturday night palsy, Radial tunnel syndrome

Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN) (Option D ruled out)

Inability to flex thumb and index finger (loss of flexion of distal phalanges)

No sensory loss (pure motor neuropathy)

Inability to make "OK" sign (difficulty flexing thumb and index finger)

Long Thoracic Nerve

Weakness of serratus anterior muscle, affecting scapular movement

No sensory loss

Winged scapula (scapula protrudes from the back)

.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness during daily activities. On examination, she is unable to make an 'O' shape by opposing her thumb and index finger. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Abductor Pollicis Brevis

Explanation:

The patient’s inability to make an 'O' shape with the thumb and index finger (tip-to-tip pinch) is a classical sign of anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) syndrome, which is a pure motor branch of the median nerve.
 

The AIN innervates deep forearm muscles, specifically:
 

  • Flexor pollicis longus
     
  • Lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus
     
  • Pronator quadratus
     

Hence, the actual motor deficit is due to involvement of FPL and FDP to the index, not due to abductor pollicis brevis or any thenar muscle.
 

However, none of the muscles directly innervated by AIN are listed in the options.
 

Among the choices, the only muscle purely and entirely innervated by the median nerve is abductor pollicis brevis, making it the most appropriate answer based on:
 

  • The nerve implicated (median),
     
  • The pattern of weakness,
     
  • And the available options.
     

Muscles of the Palm: Functions and Innervations

 

 

Muscle Group

Muscles

• Flexor pollicis brevis

Controls movement of little finger

Ulnar nerve (superficial branch)

 

Opponens pollicis (Option A): Incorrect because it is mainly innervated by the median nerve, but may receive a contribution from the ulnar nerve (dual innervation). Also, it is responsible for thumb opposition, not for the tip-to-tip pinch affected in AIN palsy.
 

Flexor pollicis brevis (Option C): Incorrect. It has dual innervation (superficial head by median, deep head by ulnar). Not purely median.
 

Palmar interossei (Option D): Incorrect. These are ulnar nerve-innervated muscles, unrelated to thumb-index pinch or median nerve pathology.

questions.text: An absent gag reflex can result from injury to which cranial nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 9 and 10

  • Cranial Nerves IX (Glossopharyngeal) and X (Vagus): The gag reflex involves both sensory and motor components. The sensory component of the gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which detects the stimulus at the back of the throat. The motor component is controlled by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), which causes the muscles in the throat to contract. Injury to either of these nerves can result in an absent gag reflex.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 10 and 7:

  • While cranial nerve X (vagus) is involved in the gag reflex, cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) is not. The facial nerve primarily controls muscles of facial expression, not the gag reflex.

Option C - 7 and 5:

  • Incorrect: Cranial nerve V (trigeminal) provides sensation to the face and motor control for mastication, and cranial nerve VII controls facial expression. Neither of these nerves is involved in the gag reflex.

Option D - 5 and 9:

  • While cranial nerve IX (glossopharyngeal) is involved in the gag reflex, cranial nerve V (trigeminal) is not. The trigeminal nerve is responsible for facial sensation and chewing.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Internal capsule

Explanation:

Internal Capsule

  • The internal capsule is a compact bundle of projection fibres that connects the cerebral cortex with subcortical centres such as the thalamus, brainstem, and spinal cord.
  • It contains both afferent (sensory) fibres from the thalamus to the cortex and efferent (motor) fibres from the cortex to the cerebral peduncle and midbrain.

INTERNAL CAPSULE:

  • V-shaped projection fiber—angled laterally, present between thalamus and caudate nucleus medially and lentiform nucleus laterally.

Parts of Internal Capsule:

  • Anterior limb: Between caudate nucleus medially and lentiform nucleus laterally.
  • Posterior limb: Between thalamus medially and lentiform nucleus laterally.
  • Genu: Between anterior and posterior limb.
  • Sublentiform: Present below the lentiform.
  • Retrolentiform: Present behind lentiform.

Lesion of Internal Capsule

  • Occurs due to hemorrhage, leading to spastic paralysis (due to involvement of pyramidal and extrapyramidal fibers for the upper limb, trunk, and lower limb) and loss of sensations in the opposite half of the body.
  • Most commonly involved artery – Charcot’s artery of cerebral hemorrhage (striate branches from middle cerebral artery).
  • Lesions in the sublentiform and retrolentiform parts of the internal capsule lead to visual loss and auditory defects.

 

 

(Option B, C, and D ruled out)

questions.text: While administering epidural anesthesia, which structure is not punctured before injecting the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Arachnoid mater

Explanation:

  • The arachnoid mater is not punctured while administering epidural anesthesia.
  • The arachnoid mater extends up to the S2 vertebrae.
  • The arachnoid and the dura matter are punctured while performing lumbar puncture.

Structures pierced to reach epidural space:

questions.text: Which artery is involved in Lateral medullary syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Explanation:

  • The occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome.

Wallenberg syndrome:

  • Also known as Lateral medullary syndrome

Pathology:

  • Blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus.
  • Damage to the lateral segment of the medulla posterior to the inferior olivary nucleus.

Clinical manifestation:

Anatomical location

Presenting clinical feature

Nucleus ambiguous gives fibers to IX, X, and XI cranial nerves

Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx

Spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve

Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss

Lateral spinothalamic tract

Contralateral body pain and temperature loss

Vestibular nuclei

Vertigo

Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum

Ipsilateral ataxia

Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord

Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a swelling below the ear and complains of pain in the lobule of the ear. The patient also reports difficulty in completely closing the left eye and experiences trouble while eating food. What nerve is most likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Facial nerve

Explanation:

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) controls facial expressions, including eye closure and smiling. Damage to it can cause weakness or paralysis in these muscles. Additionally, it regulates muscles for eating and swallowing, which aligns with the patient's eating difficulties.

External Ear consists of two main parts:

  • Pinna (Auricle)
  • External Auditory Meatus

Aspects

Auricle (Pinna)

External Auditory Meatus

Composition

Elastic cartilage, except lobule (fibrofatty tissue)
  • Cartilaginous part (Outer 1/3) with hair and ceruminous glands
  • Bony part (Inner 2/3), with thin skin continuous with the tympanic membrane, lacks hair and glands.

Parts
  • Concha (Depression leading to the external meatus)
  • Helix (Prominent rim with anterior and posterior limbs)
  • Antihelix (Parallel ridge to the helix)
  • Tragus & Antitragus (Separated by inter-tragic notch)
  • Cymba Conchae (Above crus of helix)
  • Lobule (Soft, fleshy part below antitragus)

Nerve Supply

Lateral Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve (C2, C3)
  • Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Concha: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) (Alderman’s Nerve)

 

Medial Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve
  • Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2)
  • Roof & Anterior Wall: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Floor & Posterior Wall: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X)

 

Clinical Relevance

McEwen’s triangle (Cymba Conchae)

  • It is a surgical landmark on the temporal bone to locate the mastoid antrum.

Furuncles (cartilaginous part) susceptible to infections

 

 

 

Greater Auricular nerve (Option A): Damage to this nerve might result in altered sensation around the ear, but it wouldn't explain the symptoms mentioned in the case.

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option B): provides sensation to the external ear and part of the scalp. However, it doesn't control facial movement, eye closure, or eating functions.

Vagus nerve (Option D): While damage to the vagus nerve might cause some difficulties in swallowing and speech, it would not explain the specific symptoms of facial muscle weakness, inability to close the eye, or earlobe pain described in the case.

questions.text: Which structure is not present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tail of the caudate nucleus:

  • The tail of the caudate nucleus is not present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. The caudate nucleus is part of the basal ganglia and its tail arches around and terminates in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hippocampus:

  • The hippocampus is present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is a key structure involved in memory and spatial navigation.

Option C - Fimbriae:

  • The fimbriae of the hippocampus are present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. They are bundles of axons that emerge from the hippocampus and converge to form the fornix.

Option D - Collateral eminence:

  • The collateral eminence is a ridge on the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle caused by the underlying collateral sulcus. It is indeed present in the floor of the inferior horn.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level shown by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4-L5

Explanation:

  • If the blue line is at the L4-L5 level, then this option is correct. L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts.

 

L2-L3 (Option A): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. The L2-L3 level would be higher up on the spine, and if the blue line is visibly at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

L5-S1 (Option C): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L5-S1 refers to the intervertebral space between the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5) and the first sacral vertebra (S1), which is lower down the spine. If the blue line is at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

L3-L4 (Option D): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L3-L4 refers to the intervertebral space between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). If the blue line is visible at the L4-L5 level, then this option is not the correct answer.

questions.text: The patient presented with ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body. Which artery is involved in the syndrome based on clinical features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body is suggestive lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome.
  • The occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome.

 

Wallenberg syndrome:

  • Also known as Lateral medullary syndrome

 

Pathology:

  • Blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus.
  • Damage to the lateral segment of the medulla posterior to the inferior olivary nucleus.

Clinical manifestation:

Anatomical location

Presenting clinical feature

Nucleus ambiguous gives fibers to IX, X, and XI cranial nerves

Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx

Spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve

Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss

Lateral spinothalamic tract

Contralateral body pain and temperature loss

Vestibular nuclei

Vertigo

Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum

Ipsilateral ataxia

Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord

Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis

 

 

 

Superior cerebellar artery (Option B):

  • The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior portion of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain.
  • While it can lead to symptoms like ataxia or vertigo, it doesn’t typically cause the specific signs described (ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature in the body).

Basilar artery (Option C): NA blockage in the basilar artery can lead to locked-in syndrome or other pontine deficits

Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) (Option D): AICA strokes can cause symptoms like vertigo, ataxia, and facial weakness.

questions.text:
Arrange the neural columns in medial-to-lateral order in the floor of fourth ventricle

1. Special somatic afferent

2. Special visceral afferent

3. General somatic afferent

4. General somatic afferent
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GVA, SVA, GSA, SSA

Explanation:

  • The neural columns are arranged in the alar lamina of the developing spinal cord in the following order: Medial to lateral: GVE → SVE → SE → GVA →SVA → GSA → SSA

 

Functional Columns and Nuclei of Cranial Nerve:

  • Sulcus limitans divides the mantle zone of brain stem and spinal cord into anterior motor efferent basal plate and posterior sensory afferent alar plate.

 

Afferents and efferents from brainstem:

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the marked area in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Explanation:

  • The highlighted structure is the inferior cerebellar peduncle, a white matter bundle linking the medulla oblongata to the cerebellum.
  • It is mainly supplied by the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery.

Blood supply of various parts of brain:

Structure

Blood Supply

Medulla
  • Anterior spinal artery
  • Posterior spinal artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Medullary branch from basilar artery

Pons
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Pontine branch from basilar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery

Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery

Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery

Cerebellum
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery

 

Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (Option B): The anterior inferior cerebral artery (AICA) a branch of the basilar artery, supplies blood to the anteroinferior cerebellum, middle cerebellar peduncle, and inferolateral pons.

Superior cerebellar artery (Option C): Superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, superior and middle cerebellar peduncles, and the lower midbrain.

Posterior Cerebral Artery (Option D): The Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) provides blood supply to the occipital cortex, inferior and medial temporal cortices, thalamus, and rostral midbrain.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is derived from the marked point in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ribs

Explanation:

  • Structures derived from the paraxial mesoderm include the somites.
  • Somites are bilaterally paired blocks of mesoderm that form on either side of the neural tube during early embryonic development.
  • The somites give rise to various structures in the embryo, including the axial skeleton (such as vertebrae), skeletal muscles, and the dermis of the skin.

Intraembryonic Mesoderm/ Secondary Mesoderm:

  • Formed by the proliferation of cells from the primitive streak.
  • Separates the ectoderm and endoderm except in specific regions that remain bilaminar throughout life:
    • Prochordal plate (future oral cavity)
    • Cloacal membrane (future anal and urogenital openings)
    • Midline caudal to the prochordal plate

Formation of intraembryonic mesoderm. (B) is a section along axis in (A)

  • Subdivisions:

 

1. Paraxial Mesoderm

2. Lateral Plate Mesoderm

3. Intermediate Mesoderm

Located on either side of the notochord and becomes thick.

It forms a thinner layer located laterally.

A longitudinal strip found between the paraxial and lateral plate mesoderm.

It forms:

  • Somitomeres: Form mesoderm and muscles of the head and jaw.
  • Somites: Form midline axial skeleton, skeletal muscles and dermis of back.

It forms:

  • Somatopleuric (parietal) layer: Forms connective tissue of the body wall and limbs, such as appendicular skeleton bones , muscles and dermis of periphery.
  • Splanchnopleuric (visceral) layers: Forms connective tissue and smooth muscle layers of the gut, cardiac muscle and the circulatory system.

It forms:

  • Urinary and genital systems.

Somites:

  • Paraxial mesoderm becomes segmented to form 42-44 pairs of somites develop on either side of the neural tube and notochord.
  • Appear between the 20th and 30th day, marking the 4th week as the somite period.
  • Somite Structure:
    • Sclerotome: Ventromedial part; forms vertebral column and ribs.
    • Dermatome: Lateral part; forms dermis of skin and subcutaneous tissue.
    • Myotome: Intermediate part; forms striated muscle.

 

 

Kidneys (Option B): Kidneys are the derivatives of the intermediate mesoderm.

Dorsal root ganglion (Option C): Dorsal root ganglia are derived from the neural crest cells.

Parietal pleura (Option D): The pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities, housing vital organs, originate from the lateral plate mesoderm during embryonic development.

questions.text:
The marked structure relays efferents to which nucleus of the thalamus?

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anterior nucleus of thalamus

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the fornix.
  • Fornix is the major efferent tract of the hippocampus.
  • The fornix sends efferents to the mammillary bodies, and the mammillothalamic tract connects the mammillary bodies to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus.
  • This pathway is part of the Papez circuit, involved in memory and emotional processing.

Thalamic Nuclei and their Connection:

  • Anterior nucleus
    • Receives input from hypothalamic mammillary nuclei via mammillothalamic tract.
    • Receives input from the hippocampus via fornix.
    • Projects fibers to the cingulate gyrus.
  • Dorsomedial nucleus
    • Part of the limbic system.
    • Lesion results in memory loss (Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome).
  • Intralaminar nuclei
    • Receives input from the reticular formation.
    • Projects fibers to the neocortex.
    • Sends fibers to other thalamic nuclei (unlike other thalamic nuclei, which project to different cortical areas).
  • Dorsal tier nucleus
    • Lateral dorsal nucleus: Posterior extension of the anterior nucleus.
    • Pulvinar:
      • Largest thalamic nucleus.
      • Receives input from the lateral and medial geniculate bodies.
      • Integrates visual and auditory input.
  • Ventral tier nucleus
    • Ventral anterior nucleus:
      • Receives input from globus pallidus and substantia nigra.
      • Projects fibers to the motor cortex.
    • Ventral posterior nucleus:
      • Contains three subnuclei:
        • Ventral posterolateral (VPL): Receives input from spinothalamic tracts and medial lemniscus.
        • Ventral posteromedial (VPM): Receives input from trigeminothalamic tracts.
        • Ventral posterior inferior (VPI): Receives input from vestibular nuclei.

 

Lateral nucleus of thalamus (Option B): The lateral nucleus functions as the hunger center, promoting eating when stimulated, while its destruction leads to starvation.

Ventro-postero-lateral nucleus of thalamus (Option C): The ventro-postero-lateral nucleus of the thalamus processes sensations like pain, vibration, proprioception, and light touch from the spinothalamic tract and dorsal column pathways.

Posterior nucleus of the thalamus (Option D): The posterior nucleus aids in thermoregulation by promoting heat conservation. It triggers the sympathetic nervous system, causing peripheral vasoconstriction to retain heat.
