questions.text: Please identify the structure indicated in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pons:

  • The marked structure in the image is the pons.
  • It is visible on an MRI or CT scan as a larger bulge in the brainstem.
  • In a sagittal section, the pons may appear as a larger, oval-shaped structure located below the midbrain and above the medulla oblongata. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Midbrain:

  • In a sagittal section, the midbrain may appear as a small round structure located above the pons and below the thalamus.
  • It is located anterior to the fourth ventricle and has a distinctive "butterfly" shape on axial views.

Option C - Medulla oblongata:

  • The medulla oblongata is visible on an MRI or CT scan as a tapering structure that connects the brainstem to the spinal cord.
  • In a sagittal section, the medulla oblongata may appear as a smaller, pointed structure located below the pons.
  • The medulla oblongata appears as a tapering structure that connects the brainstem to the spinal cord and is located at the bottom of the brainstem.

Option D - Spinal cord:

  • The spinal cord is located within the spinal canal, which is formed by the vertebrae of the spine.
  • In a sagittal section, the spinal cord may appear as a central canal surrounded by white matter and gray matter.

questions.text: The structure indicated in the provided image originates from the
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hippocampus

  • This image shows coronal section of brain and marked structure is fornix.
  • The hippocampus is a curved structure located in the medial temporal lobe and is closely associated with memory and spatial navigation. The fornix arises from the hippocampus and serves as the major output pathway from this structure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mamillary body: The mamillary bodies, found in the hypothalamus, are involved in regulating physiological processes. Although the fornix is connected to them, it doesn't originate from the mamillary bodies.

Option C - Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a central relay for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex. While it connects with many brain structures, it isn't the source of the fornix.

Option D - Amygdala: The amygdala, deep in the temporal lobe, processes emotions and memory. While linked to the hippocampus and part of the limbic system, it isn't where the fornix originates.

questions.text: What is the destination of the relayed signals from the Purkinje cells in the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dentate Nucleus

  • Purkinje cells of the cerebellum relay their signals into the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei located within the cerebellum. It receives input from the Purkinje cells located in the cerebellar cortex.
  • The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a crucial role in motor coordination and planning.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Caudate nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a part of the basal ganglia, which is involved in motor control. It does not directly receive input from the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.

Option B - Lentiform nucleus:The lentiform nucleus, part of the basal ganglia, includes the globus pallidus and putamen. Like the caudate nucleus, it doesn't directly relay signals from Purkinje cells of the cerebellum..

Option D - Red nucleus: The red nucleus in the midbrain aids in motor coordination, receiving input from the cerebellum, but not specifically from Purkinje cells. Its primary output targets the spinal cord and brainstem.

questions.text: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - C-Hypothalamus:

  • The image shows the mid-saggital section of brain , the wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus as the structure marked as ‘C’ corresponds to the pituitary gland.

Incorrect Options:

  • Choices A, C, D are incorrect as they are matched with the respective structures in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Proprioception

  • Proprioception, which refers to the sense of body position and movement, is not primarily processed by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Proprioceptive information from the face and head is primarily conveyed through other sensory pathways, such as the proprioceptive fibers within cranial nerves like the facial nerve (CN VII) and glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Temperature: Temperature sensations from the face and head are transmitted through the trigeminal nerve and processed in the spinal nucleus.

Option B - Pain: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve processes pain sensations from the face and head.

Option C - Touch: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve also processes touch sensations from the face and head. It receives sensory input related to light touch, pressure, and tactile sensations.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Broca’s Area

  • Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere, controls speech production by coordinating motor movements. Damage to this area can cause Broca's aphasia or expressive aphasia, characterized by difficulty forming words and producing fluent speech. While speech is impaired, comprehension usually remains intact.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in receptive aphasia or Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by impaired language comprehension and fluent but nonsensical speech.

Option C - Heschl's area: Heschl's area, the primary auditory cortex in the superior temporal gyrus, processes auditory information. Damage here isn't likely to cause the described symptoms.

Option D - Striate area: The striate area is involved in visual processing and is not directly associated with language production or comprehension.

questions.text: Which muscle among the following is not innervated by the structure labeled as A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superior oblique:

Superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the structure marked A, which is the oculomotor nerve.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The oculomotor nerve innervates the superior rectus muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eye and medially rotating it.

Option C - The oculomotor nerve innervates the medial rectus muscle, which is responsible for adducting the eye (moving it inward towards the midline).

Option D - The oculomotor nerve innervates the LPS muscle, which is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid.

questions.text: Which pathway provides afferent fibers to the mammillary body, a structure located beneath the brain's surface?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fornix:

  • The fornix is a bundle of nerve fibers that plays a crucial role in the limbic system, including its connection with the mammillary body. The mammillary bodies receive afferent fibers via the fornix, which connects the hippocampus (a critical component of the limbic system) to the mammillary bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Corpus callosum: The corpus callosum connects the brain's two hemispheres but isn't directly involved in the afferent pathways to the mammillary body.

Option B - Thalamus: While the thalamus is interconnected with the mammillary body through neural circuits, it does not directly send afferent fibers to the mammillary body.

Option C - Pituitary gland: Although pituitary gland has connections with the hypothalamus, it does not send afferent fibers to the mammillary body.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is accompanied by his wife to the Neurology OPD. His wife expressed concern about her husband's condition and they were directed to this facility by a local doctor. According to the doctor's note, the patient is unable to repeat spoken words, but can comprehend them and respond appropriately by nodding. The patient also experiences difficulty in naming people and writing. The doctor referred the patient to a specialized facility for a CT brain scan. As the intern on duty, you would inform the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) that this condition could be indicative of a brain lesion in which specific area?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Arcuate fasciculus

Difficulty in repeating spoken words, trouble with naming and writing, yet intact comprehension of spoken language, suggests Conduction Aphasia. It's caused by a disconnection between language centers in the brain, possibly affecting the Arcuate Fasciculus. This white matter tract links Broca's area (speech production) with Wernicke's area (language comprehension). Damage here can lead to symptoms like those described in conduction aphasia, where patients struggle to repeat words or phrases accurately despite understanding them.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Anterior commissure: The anterior commissure is involved in the connection between the two cerebral hemispheres but is not typically associated with the specific language symptoms described.

Option C - Corpus callosum:  Damage to the corpus callosum can result in a variety of symptoms but is not specifically associated with the language deficits described.

Option D - Fornix: The fornix is a white matter structure involved in memory processes but is not typically associated with the language symptoms described.

questions.text: The nerve of the second branchial arch is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Facial nerve

  • The nerve of the second branchial arch is the facial nerve.
  • During embryonic development, the branchial arches form the basic structure of the face and neck, and each branchial arch is associated with specific cranial nerves. The second branchial arch is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve is associated with the third branchial arch

Option C - Trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V): The trigeminal nerve is associated with the first branchial arch

Option D - Vagal nerve (cranial nerve X): The vagal nerve is associated with the fourth and sixth branchial arches, not the second arch.

questions.text: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior

  • The anterior fontanelle closes between 18-24 months after birth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Posterior: The posterior fontanelle close, usually by the age of 2 to 3 months. Therefore, it is not the last fontanelle to close.

Option C - Occipital: The occipital fontanelle is not a term used to describe a fontanelle. The occipital region of the skull refers to the back of the head, but it does not specifically indicate the presence of a fontanelle.

Option D - Mastoid: The mastoid fontanelle close, usually by the age of 1 year Therefore, it is not the last fontanelle to close.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not a part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trochlear nerve

  • The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is primarily involved in eye movement, specifically the downward and inward rotation of the eye.
  • It is part of the general somatic efferent column.
  • It does not have a role in special visceral afferent functions such as taste or smell.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) carries taste sensations from the front two-thirds of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Option C - Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries taste sensations from the epiglottis and lower pharynx to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Option D - Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) transmits taste sensations from the back one-third of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius via the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

questions.text: Broca’s area is situated in the_________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inferior frontal gyrus

  • Broca's area, also known as Brodmann area 44 and 45, is a region of the brain associated with language production and speech articulation.
  • Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere.
  • It is specifically involved in language production and speech articulation, playing a crucial role in the ability to express oneself verbally.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior temporal gyrus: The superior temporal gyrus handles auditory processing and language comprehension but is not where Broca's area is located.

Option C - Angular gyrus:The angular gyrus, in the parietal lobe, aids in reading, writing, and math, but it is not the precise location of Broca's area..

Option D - Postcentral gyrus: The postcentral gyrus handles somatosensory data like touch and pressure, not speech production like Broca's area.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked B in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fornix

The fornix is a bundle of nerve fibers that plays a crucial role in the limbic system and is involved in memory and spatial navigation. It connects various parts of the brain, including the hippocampus and mammillary bodies. This is the structure marked as B in the image.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Pineal gland

The pineal gland is a small endocrine gland located near the center of the brain, but it is not the structure marked in the image.

Option B - Falx cerebri

The falx cerebri is a fold of dura mater that separates the two cerebral hemispheres. It is not the structure marked in the image.

Option D - Pituitary gland

The pituitary gland is an endocrine gland located at the base of the brain, but it is not the structure marked in the image.

questions.text: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Projection:

The region marked in the image is the genu of the internal capsule. The internal capsule is composed of projection fibers passing to and from the brainstem and the cerebral cortex. It consists of 3 parts: an anterior limb, a posterior limb, and a genu.

Projection fibers are neural fibers that transmit signals between the cerebral cortex and lower brain regions or the spinal cord. They carry sensory information from the peripheral nervous system to the brain (ascending pathways) and motor commands from the brain to the peripheral nervous system (descending pathways).  

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Short association: Short association fibers are neural connections that link different areas within the same cerebral hemisphere. In the internal capsule image, they wouldn't stand out prominently as it's primarily composed of projection fibers.

Option B - Long association: Long association fibers connect different cortical areas within the same hemisphere and allow for communication and integration between distant regions. They would not be expected to be specifically marked in the image of the internal capsule.

Option D - Commissural: Commissural fibers are neural fibers that connect corresponding areas in the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing for communication and integration between the left and right hemispheres.

questions.text: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore at 25th day leads to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anencephaly:

  • Failure of closure of the rostral neuropore at around the 25th day of embryonic development leads to the condition known as anencephaly.
  • Anencephaly is a severe congenital malformation characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain and skull.

Incorrect Options:

Option  A - Hydranencephaly: Hydranencephaly, marked by near-total or complete absence of cerebral hemispheres, isn't specifically due to the failure of rostral neuropore closure.

Option B - Rachischisis: Rachischisis is a severe type of spina bifida where the neural tube doesn't close along the spine's entire length, not involving rostral neuropore closure.

Option D - Spina bifida: Spina bifida, involves incomplete neural tube closure, leading to spinal cord defects, but it's not directly linked to rostral neuropore closure failure.

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by:
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Anterior cerebral artery:

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the main arteries that supply blood to the brain. It arises from the internal carotid artery and provides blood supply to the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemispheres. It also supplies blood to the fornix, which is part of the limbic system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vertebral artery: The vertebral arteries, from the subclavian arteries, ascend through vertebrae to nourish the back of the brain, but they don't directly supply the fornix.

Option B - Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid arteries are major arteries that supply blood to the anterior part of the brain, but they do not directly supply the fornix.

Option D - Middle cerebral artery: The middle cerebral artery, a major branch of the internal carotid artery, feeds blood to the lateral parts of the cerebral hemispheres but doesn't directly nourish the fornix.

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below causes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Contralateral hemiplegia:

 

  •  The highlighted area is the medullary pyramids, situated in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. Lesions here result in contralateral hemiplegia, where damage affects motor fibers crossing over to the opposite side of the body. These fibers form the corticospinal tracts, transmitting motor signals from the brain to the spinal cord and muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B -  Ataxia refers to a lack of coordination of voluntary muscle movements. Lesions in other areas of the brain, such as the cerebellum, are more commonly associated with ataxia.

Option C - Tinnitus, the perception of ringing or noise in the ears, is usually linked to auditory system problems like inner ear or auditory nerve damage, not lesions in the medullary pyramids.

Option D - Facial palsy is usually due to lesions in the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) from the pons, not the medullary pyramids.

questions.text: A woman presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria, and gait ataxia. MRI revealed an acute infarct in the right dorsolateral medulla. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Wallenberg syndrome:

  • Results from acute infarct in dorsolateral medulla region of brainstem.
  • Symptoms: Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), dysarthria (difficulty speaking), gait ataxia (unsteadiness while walking).
  • Dorsolateral medulla: Controls various functions; symptom severity varies based on infarct location and extent

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dejerine's anterior bulbar syndrome:

  • Rare condition from damage to lower part of brainstem.
  • Symptoms: Paralysis of muscles for chewing, swallowing, and speaking.
  • Different from Wallenberg syndrome, which involves dorsolateral medulla specifically.

Option C - Babinski-Nageotte syndrome:

  • Babinski-Nageotte syndrome is a term that is not commonly used in medical literature. It may refer to a combination of symptoms involving weakness or paralysis of the arm and leg on one side of the body, along with abnormal reflexes. However, this is not a well-defined syndrome

Option D - Weber syndrome:

  • Results from midbrain damage, leading to weakness or paralysis on one side of the body.
  • Other symptoms: Abnormal eye movements.
